huntYears.NOTES: This is a Limited-entry hunt that takes place on a General-season unit. You will lose your bonus points if you draw out for this hunt.

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION:
The Thousand Lakes unit is a general season hunt unit and is managed to provide deer hunting opportunity. The unit has some great deer habitat and is a popular place to hunt. In recent years the unit has experienced an increase in the deer population and an increase in the buck/doe ratio. Deer hunting has been good for those willing to hunt away from roads and ATV trails. Though not managed as a trophy unit, hunters have been noticing an increasing number of mature bucks. Deer populate the entire unit, however the highest density of deer tend to be in parts of the unit where aspen habitat is available. The southern portion of the unit is drier, and has fewer deer. During the Muzzleloader season most of the deer still tend to be in the higher elevations though some have began to move down a little. Hunter densities are not as high and the weather is often pleasant.
Remember that Capitol Reef National Park is on the eastern portion of this unit and the park is closed to hunting and ATV travel.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS: Be prepared for some rough roads and rocky trails. Always carry plenty of water and tell someone where you are hunting. There are some very remote areas on this unit.
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Be prepared for variable conditions. Check weather forecasts often.  Snow storms often occur during this hunt.  Most of the time snow will melt off within a day or so.  Be prepared for muddy or snowy road conditions.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 80~1400~750~18–20~16.7~~~~~~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
During the Muzzleloader season deer are scattered over the entire unit. Much of the buck movement is dictated by weather conditions. Bucks tend to remain higher in elevation than does until the rut gets underway. The table is above 11,000 ft elevation and generally most deer move off the Table by late September. Most of the deer tend to be at the intersection of the conifer/aspen habitats and the aspen/mountain brush/sage habitats.

Every year a few older age class bucks are taken. There is no single area that produces more than others. The key is to scout your areas before the hunt to look for the deer you want.

huntMaster.SPECIAL_PROVISIONS: This is a Limited-entry hunt that takes place on a General-season unit. You will lose your bonus points if you draw out for this hunt.
huntMaster.NOTES:
Baiting big game for the purposes of hunting is now illegal in Utah.
Click here for more information.

The use of all trail cameras (including both non-handheld transmitting and non-transmitting devices) in the harvest or to aid in the harvest of big game is prohibited between July 31 and Dec. 31. Click here for more information.
huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: REQUIRED: click here or call 1-800-221-0659 to report your harvest. You must report your harvest, even if you did not take an animal, within 30 days of the season end date that is printed on your permit; failure to do so may result in you not being able to apply for big game species in subsequent years. Submitting teeth or other biological samples from your animal, or having your animal checked by a DWR representative or CWMU operator does NOT fulfill your mandatory harvest reporting requirement.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP: BLM, USFS, SITLA with some private parcels scattered throughout the unit.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: Please refer all campground questions to the appropriate land management agency. Fish Lake and Dixie National Forest, Richfield and Loa offices. BLM offices are in Richfield.
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
There is an expansive road and trail system on this unit. All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM and USFS. Most Travel regulations are covered in their Travel Management Plans.  Please direct questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated to the Fish Lake and Dixie National Forest, Richfield and Loa offices. BLM offices are in Richfield and Escalante. The USFS has a travel map that covers most of this area. 
http://www.fs.usda.gov/main/fishlake/maps-pubs
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Sevier and Wayne counties—Boundary begins at the junction of SR-24 and SR-72; east on SR-24 to the Caineville Wash road; north along the Caineville Wash road to the Cathedral Valley road; west on the Cathedral Valley road to Rock Springs Bench and the Last Chance Desert road; north on the Last Chance Desert road to the Blue Flats road; north and east on the Blue Flats road to the Willow Springs road; north on the Willow Springs road towards Windy Peak and the Windy Peak road; west on the Windy Peak road to SR-72; south on SR-72 to SR-24. Private lands within this boundary are open to general deer hunting. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Salina, San Rafael Desert, Loa, Hanksville. Boundary questions? Call the Cedar City office, 435-865-6100.
